channel.description: Which one is better? I say tie.

item.title: Star Trek VS Star Wars
item.dc:creator: danielsangeo
item.description:
Comrade Tiki:

I wasn’t referencing the flawed in-universe notation. I was citing the case that “most animals are sentient” using a trusted in-universe source.

How one can care to follow a link and read it but not bother to read the four words that have been quoted, I do not know.

“Thus most animals are sentient” is simply referencing that the in-universe definition is flawed.

Read full topic

item.title: Star Trek VS Star Wars
item.dc:creator: danielsangeo
item.description:
Comrade Tiki:

of course ewoks are sapient

The problem arises with your link and its definition of “sentience” in the Star Wars sense. Your link defines sentience as:

“A sentient was a being with the ability to think intelligently, commonly determined by the being’s ability to speak, manipulate tools, and reason. Species that lacked this ability were classified as non-sentient, or sometimes as sub-sentient.”

Ewoks had the ability to think intelligently. In fact, I believe they were MORE intelligent than, say, Uncle Owen and Aunt Beru.

Sure, sentience and sapience have different meanings OUTSIDE the Star Wars universe, but if you’re using in-universe definitions for words to define in-universe creatures…

Read full topic

item.title: Star Trek VS Star Wars
item.dc:creator: Comrade_Tiki
item.description:
danielsangeo:

Ewoks have the ability to reason (thinking intelligently), use tools and speak, though.

The term sentient is technically incorrect for this usage, instead referring to any being with the capacity to feel sensations, such as pain; thus, most animals are sentient.

Therefore, my original claim is outrageous, that none of those creatures is sentient. It should be discarded as a joke. But the post remains comprehensible thanks to the common misconception of sentient. Star Trek has a deficit of non-sapient species.

If that’s not enough, of course ewoks are sapient. We see an ewok mourn his fallen comrade, dramatically in the midst of battle. If you don’t remember this scene, you shouldn’t have the right to vote*[/size].

  • in this poll[COLOR=‘DarkSlateGray’]†[/size][/size]

[COLOR=‘DarkSlateGray’]† on second thought, if you don’t remember this scene, you shouldn’t be able to vote for anything, you heartless bastard[/size]

Read full topic

item.description:
Comrade Tiki:

Yes, I’m saying Ewoks are non-sentient.[/size]

How in the name of God can you say Ewoks are non-sentient? They might not be advanced…living in trees and all, working with stones and such…but were we not sentient as we lived in caves? We were completely able to think, interact, and invent.

item.title: Star Trek VS Star Wars
item.dc:creator: Comrade_Tiki
item.description:
In Star Wars, you get to see a lot more aliens. Aliens who are more than just humans with some makeup. (They’re like humans with some makeup and a mask.)

And where there are aliens, they’re not portrayed as some generic hostile with some specific ship type… they’re actually on two discernible sides. At least, the intelligent aliens were. Star Trek had a severe lack of non-sentient extraterrestrials. Star Wars gave us things like Tauntauns, Rancors, Ewoks, Wampas, Space-Worms, Sarlaccs, Mynocks… . . . that’s a lot more awesomeness-per-hour than Star Trek provides.

Yes, I’m saying Ewoks are non-sentient.[/size]

Read full topic

item.title: Star Trek VS Star Wars
item.dc:creator: Someonerandm
item.description:
To me Star Wars always has a greater sense of size. Star Trek has a lot of planets, but you only ever see a few small settlements or a small city. You never get the massive feeling you get in the Star Wars movie, with their massive cityscapes. Beyond that the Enterprise seems to have a crew of about 10 with a few people who occasionally come on the ship, but none of them can do anything. Star Wars had much larger crews, with large scale battles and more people doing work all over the ships.

Read full topic

item.description:
Jeannotvb:

Like those people on YouTube who rip their own heart out to prove a Star Destroyer with 10.000 ultra l33t super cannons is stronger than a Class-XXXX Enterprise with crowbar launchers?

Although let’s be serious here, the scale of ships in both series is pretty ridiculous.

Read full topic

item.title: Star Trek VS Star Wars
item.dc:creator: Sitten_duck
item.description:
^ yeah, I am glad that I don’t read youtube comments. I find my life is much happier without them.

If I want to watch a movie with lots of action, knights with lightsabers, invisible forces and a plot line that is pretty much torn from the pages of the hero’s journey, I’ll watch Star Wars. If I want to watch a show about adventuring in space, technology, ethics, and picard I’ll watch Star trek. Trying to make argue one over the other because they are science fiction (granted one is far, far more fantasy than the other), set in space, and have ‘Star’ at the beginning of their title is one of the most retarded and shallowest comparisons of the two that one can make.

Read full topic

item.title: Star Trek VS Star Wars
item.dc:creator: Jeannotvb
item.description:
Sitten_duck:

Star Trek and Star Wars are two completely different beasts in my own opinion, And I like them each for their own differences. I would delve deeper into why I think this way, but I will be late for work so I’ll sum it up by saying trying to argue whats better, Star Trek and Star Wars is like arguing whats better apples or oranges. They are two completely different fruits with different uses. Only idiots would try to argue between the two. Just enjoy both of them for what they are.

Like those people on YouTube who rip their own heart out to prove a Star Destroyer with 10.000 ultra l33t super cannons is stronger than a Class-XXXX Enterprise with crowbar launchers?

Read full topic
